{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Use British English|date=July 2016}} {{Multiple issues| {{Notability|Music|date=August 2010}} {{refimprove|date=January 2010}} }} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Hitechjet | image = Hitechjet_live.jpg | caption = | image_size = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[London]], England | genre = [[Punk rock|Punk]]
[[Indie rock]]
[[Post-hardcore]] | years_active = 2001–2006, 2012 | label = [[In At The Deep End Records]] | associated_acts = [[The Megadudes]]
[[Old Major (band)]]
[[Senseless Things]]
[[Down Love]] | website = [http://www.myspace.com/hitechjet] | current_members = Adam Gardner
Aydogan Mehmet
Brian Ayers
Micky Wyle
Paul Lefley-Evans | }} '''Hitechjet''' were an English [[rock music|rock]] [[musical ensemble|band]] from [[Uxbridge]], London, formed in 2001. Hitechjet released one mini album "If you take anything..." and one full-length album "600 miles from..." through In At The Deep End Records. Hitechjet has been on hiatus since 2006. ==Formation== Hitechjet formed in Autumn 2001 by Paul Lefley-Evans (bass), Adam Gardner (guitar), Aydogan Mehmet (guitar) and Micky Wyle (drums). They were joined at the beginning of 2002 by Brian Ayers(vocals) and became Hitechjet after a line from the [[Nena]] song [[99 Red Balloons]].{{cite web|url=http://www.myspace.com/hitechjet |title=Hitechjet | Listen and Stream Free Music, Albums, New Releases, Photos, Videos |website=Myspace.com |date= |accessdate=2020-06-03}} Hitechjet recorded their first demo with [[John Hannon]] ([[Hundred Reasons]], [[Kids Near Water]]) engineering and producing. The demo contained the songs 'The Score', 'If my best is not enough' and 'All this time'. The demo received positive reviews from fanzines and sparked interest from several record labels interested in releasing their material. Nottingham based label In At the Deep End Records were due to attend their band [[The Killerest Expression]]'s show in Leeds when Hitechjet were added to the bill. Although this was only their second show, based on their performance that night offered Hitechjet a recording contract.{{cite web |url=http://homepage.ntlworld.com/mark.swinney/hitechjet.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=17 January 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604044806/http://homepage.ntlworld.com/mark.swinney/hitechjet.htm |archive-date=4 June 2011 |url-status=dead }} ==If you take anything== In June 2003 Hitechjet released, '[[If you take anything...]]', a 7 track mini-album which received critical acclaim in many magazines and fanzines including [[Kerrang]] (4K), [[Big Cheese (magazine)|Big Cheese]] (4/5) and [[Drowned in Sound]] (9/10).{{cite web |url=http://homepage.ntlworld.com/mark.swinney/iatde015.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=22 January 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604045132/http://homepage.ntlworld.com/mark.swinney/iatde015.htm |archive-date=4 June 2011 |url-status=dead }}{{cite web|last=Hocking |first=Mat |url=http://drownedinsound.com/releases/3379/reviews/7275 |title=Album Review: Hitechjet - If You Take Anything / Releases / Releases // Drowned In Sound |website=Drownedinsound.com |date=2003-06-18 |accessdate=2020-06-03}} This led to shows with [[Lagwagon]], [[Get Cape. Wear Cape. Fly]], [[Kasabian]], [[Instruction (band)|Instruction]], [[Red Animal War]], [[Million Dead]] amongst others. ==600 miles from...== The album was recorded, engineered and produced by longtime producer [[John Hannon]]. The album was presented to In At the Deep End Records in October 2004. A 14-date first UK headline tour was booked for February 2005 to coincide with the release of the album. Artwork problems delayed the release of the album, and this led to Hitechjet leaving for their tour with their friends [[Driving on the Right]] without an album to promote. This was their most successful tour to date with several shows selling out. Due to a busy release schedule, [[In At the Deep End Records]] finally released "600 miles from..." in October 2005. Although Hitechjet were known for their "genre hopping" style, '[[600 miles from...]]' explored new areas for Hitechjet with elements of post rock, electronica and post punk and contained heavy use of samples. The album was greeted with more critical acclaim receiving 8/10 in ''[[Rock Sound]]'', 5/5 [[Big Cheese (magazine)|''Big Cheese'']], 5/5 [[Zero Magazine (music magazine)|''Zero Magazine'']], 4.5/5 Punktastic.com{{cite web |url=http://homepage.ntlworld.com/mark.swinney/iatde023.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=22 January 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604045114/http://homepage.ntlworld.com/mark.swinney/iatde023.htm |archive-date=4 June 2011 |url-status=dead }}{{cite web|author= |url=http://punktastic.com/reviews/hitechjet-600-miles-from/ |title=HiTechJet – 600 Miles From… |website=Punktastic.com |date=2005-10-22 |accessdate=2020-06-03}} amongst them. After playing 'Making Movies' regularly on his show,{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio1/mikedavies/tracklistingarchive.shtml?20050927 |title=Radio 1 - Mike Davies - Tracklisting |publisher=[[BBC]] |date= |accessdate=2020-06-03}} Radio One DJ [[Mike Davies (broadcaster)|Mike Davies]], invited Hitechjet to record a session for the Lock Up show at the end of 2005. They played live '(I should have left you at the) Roadside', 'Perfect Video (full band version)', 'This Lift goes down' and 'As though nothing happened'. In April 2006, after touring with [[The Once Over Twice]], Hitechjet's frustrations with their future and their label was beginning to cause tensions within the band. Hitechjet decided to go on an "indefinite hiatus".{{cite web |url=http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendId=2477648&blogId=111286342 |title=Archived copy |access-date=17 January 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207065936/http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view |archive-date=7 February 2009 |url-status=dead }} In July 2012, Hitechjet reformed for two one off shows in London. One with Milloy for their final London show, and the other for a friend's private party. ===Line-up=== * Adam Gardner - guitars * Aydogan Mehmet (aka "Mem") - guitar, vocals * Brian Ayers - lead vocals * Michael Wyle (aka "Micky") - drums, vocals * Paul Lefley-Evans (aka "Bev") - bass, vocals ==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''[[600 miles from...]]'' (2005) ===Mini album=== * ''[[If you take anything...]]'' (2003) ===Compilations=== * ''Punk Academy Volume 1 '' - (2003, features "The Score- (original demo)") ==Post Hitechjet== Micky Wyle performed for a reformed [[Senseless Things]] (filling in for [[Morgan Nicholls]], who was unavailable) for a secret (billed as Mark Keds) four-song performance at Islington Academy, London on 4 March 2007 – over twelve years after the band last performed – as part of a gig to celebrate the life of former [[Mega City Four]] frontman Darren "[[Darren Brown (musician)|Wiz]]" Brown, who died in December 2006. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.myspace.com/hitechjet/ Myspace page] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yjvEW7dUAi0 'All this time'(live) YouTube] {{Authority control}} [[Category:British post-hardcore musical groups]] [[Category:English alternative rock groups]]
